title: Morrisons To Shut 11 Stores As Profits Plunge
text:
23   7 mins Morrisons To Shut 11 Stores As Profits Plunge   27 minutes ago View Photo 

Morrisons is planning to close another 11 stores as it seeks to grow sales and profitability within its turnaround plan. 
The chain announced its half-year results within 24 hours of confirming it was selling off its convenience store operation to concentrate on growing its core supermarket offering. 
The results for the six months to 2 August showed there was still much to do to arrest declining business, with like-for-like sales falling 2.7% in the period. 
Underlying pre-tax profits, a measure which included restructuring costs, tumbled by 35% to £117m while total profit before tax was 47% lower at £126m. 
The industry has endured a tough time amid a price war sparked by hard discounters which has put pressure on profitability across the sector. 
Chief executive David Potts, who took over earlier this year following the departure of Dalton Philips, said the group faced a "long journey" to turn around its fortunes. 
He has sought to bring in his own people in key management roles , cut head office roles and boost shop floor staff numbers in a bid to bolster the customer experience. 
Mr Potts said: "Morrisons will be an organisation that listens. During the first half, the new executive and leadership teams have been listening hard to colleagues, customers, suppliers and shareholders. 
"They tell us there is a lot for us to do. 
"The immediate priority is to deliver a better shopping trip to stabilise trading performance. Our six strategic priorities will then deliver improvement in the core supermarkets, where we have the greatest opportunity." 
Those priorities were: to be more competitive, to serve customers better, find local solutions, develop popular and useful services, to simplify and speed up the organisation and to make the core supermarkets strong again.
